Summary: Waited for bus on clear day.Say unusualy bright light in sky.Couple in care near me also saw;they got out.
divs: Sighting Details1)I was waiting for the number 3 or 4 bus(at West Champion at Prospect) near the WorkSource office here in B'ham ,when I noticed a very bright light hovering above Bellingham Bay about a mile or so from me.It was a clear day,light to no wind.2)I first noticed the object due to its size and extreme brightness.3)I had no idea what the object was in the sky,but I have never seen anything like it to this day(and I am in past thirty,and have made it a habit for years and years to look up at the sky every day in case I might see something).4)The object was about one-third the width of a Full Moon,and was entirely alight,so I didn't see any "shape".The object made no noise from my vantage point(and my hearing is very good).Also,the object hovered,but I looked harder and noticed it was moving very slowly southwards,but it did not loose altitude.5)I felt curious.I did not feel afraid,and the light wasn't blinding (I had a pair of prescription Oakleys on while observing it).I also was somewhat excited about the possibility the UFO might be extraterrestrial in origin.6)I followed the object while walking to a different bus stop (on West Holly),and told a man in a park to look out at the sky above the bay to see a UFO:he did.Then my bus arrived,by then I had lost site of the object,and would attempt to look for it while riding the bus northbound.When I disembarked,I walked about ten minutes in an area that obscured my view of the where the UFO had been seen by me (near Bellingham Technical College,at Seaview Avenue towards Roeder Avenue).What I did notice was a very bright object too bright to be a star in the same direction,but now farther west across the bay above the mountains.I went indoors for about an hour's time,when I went back outside it was dark,and could still see the unusually bright light at the same area.I walked downtown ,by that time,thirty minutes later,I no longer could see the very bright light.
